monitoringPlanCommentData.monitoringPlanComment: Some Linearity and RATA data for the Inlet split duct XMS SO2 system was not accepted by ECMPS.  This sytem auctions between two ducts.  Each duct provides half the data each hour (swithing every 7.5 minutes).  This systenm has been existence since 2003 with EPA approval.  A requsted has been made to the DAHS vendor to split the system into two systems however current programming will not allow it.  There is no place in ECMPS note fields large enough to contain the data (in ASCII format).  The removed data has been sent to Travis Johnson CAMD EPA Region 10 Representative for review and possible inclusion in the ECMPS system by other methods.   Timothy Weber 10/29/2009

> From what I been able to determine, either the ECMPS must relax its
>    strict requirements for SO2 configurations or the Monitoring Plans
>    must be changed to a multistack configuration which is not in
>    keeping with the reasons for setting it up in its current reporting
>    configuration.   ECMPS appears to allow for separate primary and
>    bypass/certified inlet  monitors on other systems.   Why not SO2?
>    I spoke with my DAHS vendor.  Evidently Centralia is not the only
>    venue with this type of configuration problem.   Centralia had long
>    discussions with the EPA while considering changing to a single
>    stack configuration and before seeking approval.   The final
>    determination by Centralia and the EPA was that there were logical
>    reasons for it.  The inlet/bypass SO2 as the high range limited the
>    over reporting SO2 if the low range was exceeded or disable for a
>    long period.   If the inlet is not the high range then SO2 goes to
>    MPC if the scrubber analyzer exceeds its range vastly over-
>    reporting SO2.  The inlet value is probably higher that real
>    scrubber output, but vastly lower than MPC.

> From what I been able to determine, either the ECMPS must relax its>    strict requirements for SO2 configurations or the Monitoring Plans>    must be changed to a multistack configuration which is not in>    keeping with the reasons for setting it up in its current reporting>    configuration. No resolution provided for the problems listed below.  MPs submitted "as is" awaiting instructions Mon 04/27/2009 11:59 AMWe have transferred your support request to the EPA.  The EPA will review your ticket and provide information about what can be done to resolve your question.David WardPerrin Quarles AssociatesOn Mon Apr 27 12:59:08 2009, Tim_Weber@transalta.com wrote:> Due to ECMPS not accepting High/Low range analyzer with different>    serial numbers I am having the following problem successfully>    submitting DAHS generated Monitoring Plans for Units BW21 and BW22.>    These units are scrubbed units with a scrubber stack and a bypass>    stack  the scrubber stack has a full CEMS suite.  The Bypass stack>    contains only an active opacity monitor.  An inlet/bypass CEMS>    located on ducts common to both the scrubber and the bypass stack>    provides SO2 indication during bypass operation and acts as the>    high range analyzer during scrubber operations.  CO2 and NOX are>    not monitored during bypass operations due to the inability to>    place flow monitors to required specifications.   The default>    Bypass data sustitution is used for those analyzers during  bypass>    periods.>> Due the the way the SO2 analyzers are utilized, these units were set>    up in a single stack configuration.  I have tried every option>    available to make the BW21 and BW22 MPs pass the ECMPS tests.>    ECMPS will not accept any code options for the SO2 analyzers other>    than Primary and NFS.  I tried to change the SO2 analyzers so there>    were no high/low designation then  make the inlet/bypass analyzer>    (high range) a Primary Bypass monitor or Certified Inlet monitor.>    ECMPs will not accept these designations for SO2 analyzer and ECMPS>    will only accept one SO2 analyzer per unit if not designated>    High/Low.>> The problem is that ECMPS does not recognize that separate analyzers>    can function as high and low SO2 analyzers;  the high and low>    analyzers need to have the same serial number.   I tried to change>    the serial numbers to match by naming them "See MP Note 1" .  I>    intended to use the note to explain the situation.  This resulted>    in a Critical Error that indicated that the systems did not have>    the same start date.  I change the analyzer and system dates  to>    match just to see and the errors went away.  They did.  So the only>    way I've found to make this configuration work is to lie to the>    system.  I don't think the EPA would be amused.    40 CFR 75>    provides for the use of separate analyzers with separate probes as>    high and low range analyzers and the methods used in these stack>    have been approved by the EPA.>

On February 19th 2014, the Moisture determination for this unit was changed from an O2 Wet/Dry system to a Moisture Saturation table.   The O2 wet/dry system proved unreliable in  all conditions and failed RATA in December of 2013.  02/19/2014 was chosen as the date for the transition as this was the day TransAlta aligned and checked the installed temperature detector accuracy.  Note that Jenny Jachim and Robert Vollaro of CAMD were consulted regarding this system change.

No resolution provided for the problems listed below.  MPs submitted "as is" awaiting instructions 

Mon 04/27/2009 11:59 AM
We have transferred your support request to the EPA.  The EPA will review your ticket and provide information about what can be done to resolve your question.

David Ward
Perrin Quarles Associates

On Mon Apr 27 12:59:08 2009, Tim_Weber@transalta.com wrote:
> Due to ECMPS not accepting High/Low range analyzer with different
>    serial numbers I am having the following problem successfully
>    submitting DAHS generated Monitoring Plans for Units BW21 and BW22.
>    These units are scrubbed units with a scrubber stack and a bypass
>    stack  the scrubber stack has a full CEMS suite.  The Bypass stack
>    contains only an active opacity monitor.  An inlet/bypass CEMS
>    located on ducts common to both the scrubber and the bypass stack
>    provides SO2 indication during bypass operation and acts as the
>    high range analyzer during scrubber operations.  CO2 and NOX are
>    not monitored during bypass operations due to the inability to
>    place flow monitors to required specifications.   The default
>    Bypass data sustitution is used for those analyzers during  bypass
>    periods.
>
> Due the the way the SO2 analyzers are utilized, these units were set
>    up in a single stack configuration.  I have tried every option
>    available to make the BW21 and BW22 MPs pass the ECMPS tests.
>    ECMPS will not accept any code options for the SO2 analyzers other
>    than Primary and NFS.  I tried to change the SO2 analyzers so there
>    were no high/low designation then  make the inlet/bypass analyzer
>    (high range) a Primary Bypass monitor or Certified Inlet monitor.
>    ECMPs will not accept these designations for SO2 analyzer and ECMPS
>    will only accept one SO2 analyzer per unit if not designated
>    High/Low.
>
> The problem is that ECMPS does not recognize that separate analyzers
>    can function as high and low SO2 analyzers;  the high and low
>    analyzers need to have the same serial number.   I tried to change
>    the serial numbers to match by naming them "See MP Note 1" .  I
>    intended to use the note to explain the situation.  This resulted
>    in a Critical Error that indicated that the systems did not have
>    the same start date.  I change the analyzer and system dates  to
>    match just to see and the errors went away.  They did.  So the only
>    way I've found to make this configuration work is to lie to the
>    system.  I don't think the EPA would be amused.    40 CFR 75
>    provides for the use of separate analyzers with separate probes as
>    high and low range analyzers and the methods used in these stack
>    have been approved by the EPA.
>
